content: There was a time, a time before cable news, when the network anchorman reigned supreme. Thank goodness those days are long gone, but like the dominant broadcasters of yore, Scott Pelley of             CBS News                   has a voice that could make a wolverine purr. Still, it’s not clear that anyone could make sense of the words that Mr. Pelley was speaking on Thursday.In a commentary for the “CBS Evening News,” Mr. Pelley began:Some of the gunshot wounds might have been self-inflicted? If CBS had discovered evidence that those attending the congressional baseball practice had actually been wounded by their own bullets, rather than shots fired by James Hodgkinson, this surely would have been the scoop of the year. But Mr. Pelley quickly made clear that he and his colleagues had no such evidence. Instead, he was suggesting that the victims of the attempted assassinations might bear some blame for motivating Hodgkinson to attack:Blaming anyone other than the shooter for attempted assassination is generally a mistake. And the timing could hardly have been worse. Mr. Pelley was intoning his commentary on the same day that victim Rep. Steve Scalise (R., La.) was undergoing one of the series of surgeries he has required since the Wednesday attack. Last weekend his condition was upgraded to serious from critical. On Thursday, the day of the Pelley commentary, shooting victim Matt Mika was also in critical condition. Capitol Police Officer Crystal Griner was also still in the hospital on Thursday, according to CNN.Given the timing and the circumstances that Mr. Pelley chose to make his case, one might have expected him to cite some truly damning rhetoric that had been uttered by the victims, if not direct evidence that they had incited Hodgkinson to carry out his bloody attack. One would have been wrong. The CBS voice offered not a shred of evidence that any of the shooting victims had done anything to create an “abyss of violent rhetoric,” or to inspire the actions of the man who tried to assassinate them. Instead, the anchorman mentioned a politician who was not targeted:Mr. Pelley offered no evidence that Hodgkinson suffered from mental illness, nor did he explain how comments by Mr. Sanders could possibly raise the question of whether the victims’ wounds might be “self-inflicted.”Believe it or not, the segment went downhill from there. The CBS newsman concluded by citing President Trump’s harsh rhetoric about his network and other media outlets, as if Mr. Pelley and his colleagues were the real victims of last week’s violence.Coincidentally on Friday Mr. Pelley left the CBS nightly anchor chair to focus on his reports for the CBS program, “60 Minutes.” The move had been announced in May and in media terms, Mr Pelley remains kind of a big deal.***Bottom Stories of the DayYes We(ed) Can  “Rand Paul And Al Franken Come Together For Weed,” Daily Caller, June 15Extra Shot of Condemnation with Your Covfefe?  “            Starbucks                   customer says she was bullied for supporting Trump,” Fox46 Charlotte, June 15Follow James Freeman on Twitter.Subscribe to the Best of the Web email with one click.To suggest items, please email best@wsj.com.(Carol Muller helps compile Best of the Web. Thanks to Ethel Fenig and Sophie Mann.)

content: Two federal agencies have joined the probe into a police car chase and fiery crash in Jersey City that critically injured a bystander.The participation of the U.S. Attorney’s Office for New Jersey and the Federal Bureau of Investigation brings the possibility of federal charges if any Jersey City police officers are found to have committed wrongdoing in the car chase and alleged subsequent beating of a bystander, a spokesman for the U.S. attorney’s office said on Tuesday.“We welcome the participation of the U.S. attorney’s office and the FBI in our investigation,” said Hudson County Prosecutor       Esther Suarez,        who is leading the investigation. “This cooperative multiagency effort will provide that which justice demands—a fair, expeditious, thorough and impartial determination of all facts.”Carmine Disbrow, president of the Jersey City Police Officers Benevolent Association, said the union supported the Hudson County prosecutor’s investigation.Last week, Jersey City suspended three officers and one lieutenant without pay for tactics used during the car chase. Mayor       Steven Fulop       has threatened to fire the officers involved in the incident.The incident occurred on the night of June 4, when police said they tried to stop a vehicle driven by       Leo C. Pinkston,        48 years old, of Jersey City.Mr. Pinkston fled and led police on a chase that lasted more than six minutes, at times driving in between two lanes of traffic, according to authorities. At one point, police opened fire on Mr. Pinkston’s vehicle, they said. The chase ended when Mr. Pinkston crashed into a utility pole, causing another vehicle carrying 28-year-old       Miguel Feliz-Rodriguez       to erupt into flames.A video taken by a witness purportedly shows Mr. Feliz-Rodriguez emerging from the car on fire before officers approach him. In the video, one officer, who appears to have his gun drawn, began kicking Mr. Feliz-Rodriguez before he is dragged onto the street by the officers. Mr. Disbrow previously said the video showed “officers acted quickly to extinguish the flames.”Mr. Feliz-Rodriguez was taken to the hospital in critical condition. A spokeswoman for St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., said on Tuesday his condition had improved to serious.Prosecutors are investigating the events that led up to the chase, the chase itself and the alleged beating captured on the video just after the crash. Ms. Suarez said previously that her office would use the video as evidence in the investigation.Mr. Pinkston was charged with attempted assault and eluding officers. His next court appearance is set for Thursday. His attorney didn’t respond to requests for comment.Write to Zolan Kanno-Youngs at Zolan.Kanno-Youngs@wsj.com
news_title: FBI, U.S. Attorney’s Office Join Probe Into Jersey City Car Chase and Crash

content: WASHINGTON—The new commissioner of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration testified before a Senate panel Tuesday without directly addressing the Trump administration’s proposal to cut $700 million from its budget.The administration calls for making up the difference by raising fees on the pharmaceutical and medical-device industries.After senators of both parties called President Donald Trump’s proposed budget “not feasible” and “woefully inadequate,”       Dr. Scott Gottlieb,        the agency’s new commissioner, ducked the issue by saying only, “The bottom line is we can always do more with more when it comes to the resources that the agency has.” Later, he added, “I wasn’t involved in the formulation of the budget.”Mr. Trump’s budget proposal, released in May, would leave a hole of more than $700 million in the $5.1-billion FDA budget, compared with this fiscal year, because the document assumes about $1.2 billion in revenue for the coming fiscal year that won’t turn up if Congress has its way. About $127 million of the money that would be cut from the budget is for safety surveillance of drugs and devices.The administration has proposed raising user fees paid by the drug and medical-device industries to the agency for new-product reviews to offset the proposed cut in taxpayer funding. But those fees have already been negotiated between the FDA and the industries at much lower levels, and Republican legislators have made clear they have no intention of insisting the FDA reopen talks to try to raise them.On Tuesday, Dr. Gottlieb testified before the subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee that oversees the FDA’s budget.At the outset of Tuesday’s hearing, subcommittee chairman Sen. John Hoeven (R., N.D.) said the administration’s estimate of new user fees is “not feasible.” Sen.       Patrick Leahy       (D., Vt.) called Mr. Trump’s plan “woefully inadequate.”Dr. Gottlieb’s prepared testimony focused on his plans at the FDA to speed up the approval of medicines for rare diseases, known as orphan drugs. Dr. Gottlieb disclosed that the agency has had a backlog of requests for orphan status, a designation that offers benefits to the drug’s sponsor, such as tax credits.He said the FDA hasn’t yet responded to about 200 applications from companies seeking orphan status. During the next 90 days, the agency plans to “completely eliminate this backlog of requests and provide an answer back to the sponsors,” Dr. Gottlieb said.“Moreover, we won’t ever again develop a backlog,” he said.The new commissioner has previously spoken about working toward speeding certain generic drugs to market in an effort to rein in drug prices. In Tuesday’s testimony, he spoke of updating guidance that the agency issues “so that we can make clinical trials more efficient.”He wasn’t specific as to how that would work, and many Democrats have expressed skepticism, suggesting such efficiency would lower safety standards.In one instance, Dr. Gottlieb said the agency is considering broad approvals for cancer drugs that hit the same genetic or molecular targets in a variety of cancers, instead of insisting on approvals for one cancer at a time.Write to Thomas M. Burton at tom.burton@wsj.comAppeared in the June 21, 2017, print edition as 'FDA Chief Sidesteps Questions on Budget.'
news_title: FDA Chief Sidesteps Questions About Trump’s Proposed Agency Budget Overhaul

content: Chicago Fed President       Charles Evans       sat down with Wall Street Journal reporters on Tuesday in New York and discussed a variety of issues facing the central bank, including the outlook for interest rate rises and the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet at a time of weak inflation. He also took answered questions on banking sector issues, productivity and Fed Chairwoman       Janet Yellen’s       performance in office.Here is a transcript of the exchange, lightly edited for length and clarity -- By Michael S. DerbyQ:  So I was just asking about inflation and the weakness of inflation that we’ve seen over the last few months, and, you know, whether or not that calls into question whether the Fed will be able to deliver on its forecast of around one more rate rise.  How long do you need to see the inflation trend pick up from where we are right now before you could support another rate rise this year?MR. EVANS:  Well, I think it’s very important that, you know, the Federal Reserve support the economy and support inflation rising to our 2% objective.  We have said that we’ve got a 2% objective going back to 2012 January, our Policy Strategy Statement, and everybody sort of understood 2% for a longer period of time is our objective.  We have not hit it in that time period.  There have been a lot of reasons why:  aftermath of the great financial crisis and disinflationary tendencies.  But more recently, inflation has been moving up from, you know, below 1% at one point, core inflation started moving up, and, you know, we’ve increased the funds rate by 100 basis points.  And so we’ve, you know, come off the zero floor and, you know, moved up to, you know, 1 1/8 average.So that’s good, but that’s all premised on an outlook where the economy is doing well.  Unemployment’s 4.3%.  Looking for growth in the 2 ¼% range, which is above trend – trend is more like 1 ¾, and that’s been enough to drive unemployment down.  But inflation—which had been moving up off of its 1 ¼, 1.4 year over year—was moving up.And now, most recently, the last three months have been quite disappointing.  There’s no other way to describe that, I would say.  Some of it looks like it’s seemingly one-off effects from cellphone company data plans and things like that.  So maybe it’s explainable, and maybe next month and the month after that we’ll revert back to better inflation.  I think that means—for me, I know it means—you know, it’s time to assess, you know, what the state of inflation is and whether or not we’re really going to move up to 2%.So the premise of your question was does this mean that we can continue raising rates.  You know, the median of the (Summary of Economic Projections) is for three rate increases this year.  We’ve done two.  I think that, you know, we’re now at a point where, you know, we can—we can afford—having raised the rate twice, we can afford to sort of wait a little bit and see how the data play out.  There’s a lot going on with uncertainty, the economy—global economy’s doing better—but to see if inflation’s going to move up.I think we could wait until the end of the year.  December is another SEP round, press conference, and that would be the time where we could decide three rate increases, two rate increases.  To get to four, we’d have to do something before that, obviously.  And for me, I think, boy, you know, if we saw better inflation and the unemployment rate, you know, continuing to move down, yeah, OK, I could see that.  But that’s not in my outlook at the moment.Q:  OK.  So, I mean, you’re willing to wait awhile to see if the inflation data do perk back up?  I mean, I guess what you’re saying is the Fed definitely has time to make a call on its next rate move.MR. EVANS:  I think so.  And that’s also—you know, that’s also in the median SEP projection.  You know, the median is for three rate increases.  We don’t say when they’re going to take place.  That’s not the nature of the exercise.  And if we got that in in December, that would be three.  But it also affords the optionality of, in December, kind of seeing, gee, you know, unemployment—inflation’s not picking up, there’s something else going on.  If unemployment continues to move down, there’s this tension between a very strong labor market, history with inflation likely around the corner, maybe it’s going to come.  It’s just that we’ve had a bit too many experiences of forecasting an upturn in inflation, having a good reason for forecasting that, and it hasn’t taken place.Q:  If you did wait until the end of the year—if conditions cause you to wait until the end of the year, would that affect the balance-sheet plan?  Because that—you know, in the new agenda, it’s hopefully this year you’re going to do that.  But if you wait until December to raise rates because that’s what the economy calls for, would that push the balance-sheet plan into 2018?MR. EVANS:  Doesn’t have to.  So the chair has spoken well on this at her press conference.  We’ve released, you know, an addendum to our normalization guidelines, you know, on this.  And so now we’ve indicated that, you know, we’ve looked at this, you know, quite carefully, and the current expectation is we put together—we have this plan, and when we decide it’s time to start reducing our balance sheet that we’ll begin taking $10 billion of assets off our balance sheet each month—basically, that’s what the cap means:  6 Treasury, 4 MBS—for the first quarter, and then that would increase by 10 billion each quarter until we get to 50 billion.  That’s enough to start reducing the balance sheet in a meaningful, noticeable way, but not too quickly.  And, you know, we can do that at any point.I personally think, and I think most people think, that once this starts it can be running in the background.  Markets will understand.  They understand the plan now.  Most of the action on the term premia, I think, comes from understanding the plan.  It’s all priced in, and you can see it run off.One way to do it, you know, (New York Fed President William) Dudley…has said, you know, maybe we make an action on the balance sheet at a meeting where we don’t have to change the funds rate.  That would be a way to take the balance sheet, get that started, and position ourselves for a December rate increase.  That’s one possibility.  There are others.  But this is one that allows that optionality that, at the moment, I prefer.Q:  And when officials say that — (the process of shrinking the balance sheet will)—start when interest rate normalization is “well under way,” what is implied by “well under way?”  Are we there now with this latest rate increase?MR. EVANS:  “Well under way,” obviously, came to be a heavily laden term.  Whenever you do qualitative guidance, it sort of takes that on.  I know a number of people have thought about what’s the level of the funds rate at which it must obviously be well under way, and you can go through a number of thought exercises on that.  And they might be somewhat north of where we are.  But I think, in general, we’ve increased the funds rate by 100 basis points.  The first time we did it, events didn’t work out; that is, uncertainty internationally in 2016.  An awful lot of things happened:  Brexit, China volatility, and all of that.  So, you know, we delayed until last December.  Now we’ve done three in a row.I mean, you know, things are pretty in train at the moment.  I recognize that’s not the same term.  But I think we’re at the point where we can make a decision to start adjusting the balance sheet at any time at this point.Q:  And in September it seems like there’s a prospect, again, for…fiscal collisions in Washington, debt-limit high jinks.  Would that affect your timing at all if you got into September and, you know, there was uncertainty over what’s going to happen there?MR. EVANS:  That’s a good question.  I’m not an expert on the exact interactions of what we do with the Treasury markets.  Obviously, we care about well-functioning Treasury markets, and so, you know, if there are concerns we’d have to think about that.  But, you know, at the moment, I’m, you know, not really that aware of exactly how that would play out.  At some point, once—you know, once Congress and the president get talking about the debt ceiling, sometimes this goes on for quite some period of time, sometimes it’s resolved more quickly.  So, you know, it’s just difficult to—you know, if you let that, you know, stop you, then you almost stop planning or whatnot.  So I think we can continue to plan along these lines.I think, as it turns out, rolling off $10 billion — $6 billion of Treasurys, those are actually assets that markets would like to have available to them during, you know, times where they value safe assets.  So I don’t think it presents too many problems.  But, again, I’m not expert, and I do know that people are concerned about that.Q:  You mentioned one-off factors sort of dragging down inflation over the last few months.  Do you expect all those one-off factors to sort of go away altogether?  Or is there ever a circumstance in which there are not one-off factors that are weighing on inflation or otherwise?MR. EVANS:  It’s a good—yeah.  So once you start picking apart pieces of the price index—you know, I think it was (former Cleveland Fed President) Jerry Jordan who way back in the ’90s had some comment like, you know, once you start diving into the elements of the price index, you begin to convince yourself that the price report creates its own inflation or whatnot.  I mean, you can just, you know, pick out what you like.  Back when tobacco prices were going up a lot due to the legal settlement, there used to be, you know, core, eggs, food, energy and tobacco prices.  And so it’s easy to do this.I think there’s a good case that these are one-off.  How many times are the, you know, phone companies going to change the data plans and things like that?  Maybe it’s a once and for all type of change.  I’m a little more—you know, I’d like to reflect on this a little bit more because, you know, the same technology, you know, at the moment is changing all the time.  It’s changing in ways that are not easy to understand.  It’s not exactly the late ’90s, when durable goods manufacturing technology was roaring along, and, you know, digital technology was finding its way on the factory work floor and offices in a big, big way in a very positive, broad fashion.Now, it’s more disruptive.  More corporations are choosing to merge, ones that you wouldn’t have thought of necessarily.  You could have been farsighted and seen that, but others, you know, not so much.  And it makes you wonder if competition is beginning to take place along lines that haven’t been contemplated.  Competition, you know, in many forms would adjust price margins.  Price margin adjustment would lead to lower price levels for—relative prices.  But you get enough of these relative prices and it finds its way into the price index, unless the stance of monetary policy is sufficiently accommodative to overcome that.And so that would be the what if it’s not exactly one-off.  Well, globally inflation has been low.  One of the commonalities across the globe—now, we’ve all suffered from the great financial crisis, OK.  Governments haven’t responded full force with fiscal actions in many cases, OK.  I mean, there are common approaches that have been taken that could account for it.  But technology is affecting the global economy as well, and demographics.  And so it’s a—it’s a very challenging time to say with certainty, yeah, I know it’s one-off.Rather, it’s really more—I mean, in fairness to the other viewpoint, I think it’s that labor markets are doing quite well.  Unemployment rate’s 4.3%.  Labor force has been—participation rate has been declining.  And there are a lot of demographic reasons for that.  Maybe we’d all prefer more people in the workforce so that we could grow faster, but people are voluntarily making these choices and people are getting older, and a whole host of demographic reasons.  So I mean, I think that’s kind of what we face.  The unemployment rate’s falling.And, you know, historically vibrant labor markets, accommodative Fed, go back to the ’70s and you kind of recoil with fear over that.  I think it’s a very different world.  I think the state of inflation expectations are very different now.  But, you know, you’d have to be not really thinking very carefully to be oblivious to that possibility.  So I think there are risks on both sides.Q:  What do you view as banks’ role right now in the economy?  Are they lending enough?  Are they overregulated?  Would you advise any tweaking there to get better economic performance?MR. EVANS:  Well, I mean, I—you know, I think bank lending is taking place, you know, reasonably well.  I don’t think that—you know, so at the moment, you know, banks have had a chance to rebuild their capital.  The demands on them to have capital in place are stronger, higher than they were before the financial crisis.  You know, you can argue over exactly how limiting that is for bank lending.  You know, there is some research that indicates that banks that have more capital end up being more profitable and do more lending.  That’s not your first reaction, I think, to the fact that more leverage usually ends up with more lending.  But I think the current circumstances are, you know, pretty good for the financial sector.Regulatory burden, yeah, I mean, it’s definitely higher than it was before the crisis.  It was probably, you know, given the fact that we got ourselves into a financial crisis, it was probably too low.  It could easily be, you know, higher now, and then part of the question would be what type of adjustments.  I think community bankers have always feared that Dodd-Frank, even with certain carve-outs, you know, the attitude of regulators and supervisors would be to just, you know, wash all of that across the spectrum of the size of banks, and that they would end up being more regulated than even their expectations, you know, from the law.I was always, you know, a little, frankly, skeptical of that.  But, you know, in fact, I’ve heard more and more and, you know, I think that that is sort of an issue.  So, you know, the Fed has started, you know, tailoring some of these requirements so that the community banks aren’t affected to the same degree.  But, you know, it’s a judgment call and certainly some things, you know, could be done.  But I do think that for the largest financial institutions that, you know, are systemically important more and better capital serves everybody better.  You know, having the appropriate liquidity on hand in the face of difficult liquidity times, I think, is important.And I think that the stress tests have served us all pretty well.  Part of the stress test involves doing horizontal reviews, and then sort of sharing the outcomes of that, having feedback with the supervisors.  I know it’s painful, but at some point a little more gets shared about, you know, I think ways to have some capital in place or some liquidity in place against certain alternatives that help people think about that.  But you can certainly go further than his ideal.Q:  Your banks that you supervise, do any go through the stress test?MR. EVANS:  Yeah.  Yeah, they’re not part of the highest (Large Institution Supervision Coordinating Committee) banks.  But they’re the large financial banking organizations, the next tier down. And over 50 billion. And also with a global presence, custody banks, Northern Trust.  We supervise HSBC as well. And Allied Bank.Q:  You seemed to hint at the question of productivity just a little bit earlier.  Where do you come out on the productivity paradox?  Any new evidence that says, so, it’s there we just can’t see it, or the opposite side of the question?MR. EVANS:  Productivity’s always difficult to measure.  So it’s definitely possible that there’s stronger productivity likely to emerge in certain areas more narrowly than broadly, you know, everywhere.  I think that, you know, the 10-year period from ’95 to 2005 was just an extraordinary period for productivity.  We had a productivity slow down before that.  There are two different five-year periods in that 10-year period.  The ’95 to 2000 period was one where capital embodied technology really improved a lot.  It’s that durable goods manufacturing, computers, you know, finally finding its way into offices.  The computer had been around for quite some time before that.  And you saw noticeable acceleration of productivity.And then after Y2K, you didn’t see that same type of productivity, but you saw what economists refer to as total factor productivity, which is the residual, after accounting for capital and labor input, growth.  And that’s just business process and improvement.  Businesses that—things had done so well in the previous five years, they left a lot of things, inefficiencies dangling because they were too busy doing other things.  And so they cleaned that up and we saw that, you know, really improve for five years.  For 10 years, that was a great productivity period.Then, you know, somewhere, and the financial crisis gets—you know, confuses things as to when the real slowdown was.  So now we’re stepping back down to something probably a little higher than the productivity slowdown in the areas of 73 to 95, but not nearly like the previous 10 years.  Maybe it’s better.  Maybe it’s improving.  But at the moment it’s disruptive.  So in the places where you see a lot of productivity increase, you see other capital investments just depreciate, because they’re not profitable in the same way.Q:  Do you guys talk about driverless cars?MR. EVANS:  Us guys who?  I mean, you know, at the (Federal Open Market Committee) level? Yeah, you know, somebody might make a comment, but not very much at the—at my board-of-directors level, a little bit more; at a business advisory group, a lot more.  And in Chicago, we’ve had a couple of gatherings with people engaged in startups, the technology incubation centers in Chicago and what not.  They’ll talk a lot about driverless cars.Q:  Detroit’s in your region.MR. EVANS:  Oh, sure.  Yeah, Detroit’s in our region.  You know, everybody’s thinking about driverless cars; insurance companies.  It’s going to be so safe. Who’s going to have an insurance policy?  There are just a whole bunch of things I don’t understand; just the mere fact that you’ve got some driverless cars on the same road with people who are driving, who like driving.Q:  Yeah, but one day—if you take that, one day it will be illegal to drive a car as a person.MR. EVANS:  This – this is a country of freedom and liberty.  (Laughter.)  And I don’t really understand that.  But OK.Q:  No, one day, however many decades out from here.  You’re too much of a danger.MR. EVANS:  In Oklahoma is that going to be the case?  I mean, there’s an awful lot—I mean, in a city, I understand this.Q:  So, just given where you think productivity is, where do you think trend (gross domestic product growth) is going to be?MR. EVANS:  A nice round number I usually say is 1 ¾.  Some people are now at 1 ½, which is a very politically fraught discussion.  I mean, I—you know, I gave a speech—beginning of last year?  No, I think it was two years ago—a bankers’ group in Wisconsin.  And I started rolling out the, you know, have you heard about the demographics in the labor force?  And, you know, this is meaning—this means that labor input’s just not going to grow as much as it did before.  And then productivity isn’t so good.  So, you know, we’re kind of thinking that growth is likely to be 1 ¾.And then in the audience afterwards there was somebody from the state government, not at the highest levels, and, you know, the person said afterwards, you know, you know, I heard what you said, and it made a lot of sense.  I just wish, instead of 1 ¾, you could have said 4%, to which I said me too, because, you know, growth solves an awful lot of problems.  And it would be good if we could get 4%.  But where does it come from?  We’re talking about two very difficult areas.  One is productivity.  I’m sorry—I think last night we were talking about our poor state of inflation forecasting or things that we don’t know so well; you know, inflation dynamics.You know, economists—you know, you could stump—you could get them to admit under oath that—not even under oath; in a conversation—that we don’t understand a lot of things in productivity, where it comes from.  You know, (economist Robert) Solow said that Solow residual was the measure of our ignorance about productivity, after accounting for capital and labor growth.Research and development helps, OK, but the relationship is, you know, probably about up there with the Phillips curve and things like that.  So we’d all like to see stronger productivity growth.  And I think if you let people innovate, you know, don’t get in their way too much, that you get better results.  But, I mean, you’re probably only going to get so much.  And it’s really the labor input that is the most limiting of all of this.Go back to the ’80s, when we saw very strong trend growth, over 3% probably, and there were a lot of people coming into the workforce, continuing to come in.  And that just added to the growth numbers.  Now that’s not likely to continue, and especially as you adjust immigration policies and things like that.  That only makes it more difficult.So you put those two things together, and 1 ¾, you know, is a very realistic estimate.  Could it be 2 ¼?  Could be, but it probably requires an awful lot of lift.Q:  How worried are you about restrictive immigration and trade policies even creating further headwinds to getting a better GDP number?MR. EVANS:  Yeah, I think—I think—yeah, I’m nervous about that.  I mean, I think that we need—we need a vibrant labor market.  We need an economy where we’re adding to labor-force growth, however we get there.  But, you know, we need to get that.  I think that most of the people who’ve left the labor force for demographic reasons—you know, men, as they get older, have less of an attachment to the labor force.  You know, every five-year bucket as they get older, they, you know, sort of choose randomly or however not to participate, you know, quite as much.  And, you know, you go through all of that.  You’re just not likely to see the strong growth rates that we saw in the ’80s, and even the ’90s, unless some other spark is introduced.Q:  What are you hearing from businesses in your district about immigration?MR. EVANS:  We don’t—we don’t really hear a lot of comments about immigration, not per se.Q:  So you’re not hearing anything about sort of, you know, restrictions and a lot of the stuff that’s happening?  Particularly in the Chicago area, it seems like there’s been some activity.MR. EVANS:  Yeah, that topic just doesn’t come up very much.  I’m sure that pharmaceutical companies, others—they’re probably H-1B visas or, you know, probably resource-constrained.  But people don’t really talk about that.You do—you do always hear that it’s just hard to find skilled workers, high-skilled workers, that type of thing.  That’s been going on for a long time; continues to go on.  And some of it’s probably forecastable; I mean, people who say that we’ve known for a long time that welders were going to be retiring and nobody really beefed up the pipeline of training welders.  Nobody was interested in the details of that.  But the higher-skilled digital technology, I think it’s very challenging.  And the interaction with immigration, visas, is not helpful.Q:  Just on the unknowns side of things, just to come back to the balance sheet, how much time do you think you need to give the market between some kind of reveal that things are going to get, you know, started, versus we are now starting?  I think this—I don’t think Chair Yellen answered the question about whether the announcement and something forthcoming would be a month apart or maybe three months apart.  And I know there’s been some discussion of the phasing in of that.  I just wondered how much time you feel you need to give the market between point A and point B, particularly the mortgage market, which may need a little bit more time than the Treasury market.MR. EVANS:  Yeah.  I read her transcript.  I guess I didn’t take strong note of the issue that you’re pointing to.For me, I think that we’ve laid out as much detail on this as anybody needs to sort of understand what they would be facing in terms of additional supply coming on the market from us, not reinvesting fully everything that matures.  We’ve announced that it’s going to be a very slow start.  Treasurys, I think, are the easiest.  The (mortgage-backed securities) is more complicated. There’s a lot of (inaudible) action and things like that.But I think that, you know, the New York desk will have additional commentary looking at the, you know, maturity structure of Treasurys.  I, you know, had to even ask my staff sort of like, when we talk about reinvesting or rolling over, and how does that get distributed?  And one of the answers I got back was, oh, it’s the same way we’re doing now, it’s just a little bit less of it.  Which kind of reminded me I hadn’t be paying attention to all of the details of three- to five-year, you know, notes maturity and things like that.  So I think the markets probably, you know—I can’t imagine why the markets don’t understand on the basis of what we’ve already laid out.Q:  They do, but I think there’s, like, another—there’s another widening that might come when you actually get started, so.Q:  I mean, like, let’s say you start—let’s say you decide you’re going to start on November 1st.  When do you say—when do you tell folks, hey, we’re going to start this on November 1st?  Is that sort of what you’re trying to get at?Q:  It’s sort of the—whether it’s flush, in the same meeting, or whether there’s like a month’s gap or even two months of a gap, bearing in mind there’s, you know, a potential rate increase in December and you might not want to do two things overlapping in the same meeting.MR. EVANS:  Oh, you know, some things are—some things, in my mind, are a little bit more of a detail orientation, and I trust the New York Desk, you know, to keep people—to be, you know, advertising and consulting with, you know, big—you know, a whole bunch of people who are affected by this.  I think that a lot of work has already been done.  Speeches have been given.I think that it could be done just by we go into a meeting and then we say we’ve just decided that we’re going to do this, and, you know, perhaps it begins, you know, whatever the 1st of the next month is, something like that.  Or it could be that it’s decided and then we say, you know, a couple of months.  I guess if we found ourselves in—unsure about the Treasury discussions over the debt ceiling, it could be that we make an announcement and then it’s, you know, got a little bit of a delay.  But I’m not quite sure why that would have to be very long.Q:  There’s a high bar to not continuing the rate rising campaign, but is there as much of a high bar to not continuing the balance-sheet actions?  I mean, what would make you hold off this year—from this year?MR. EVANS:  Yeah, I think of it this way.  I’m not really expecting—oh, people involved in the markets, it’s definitely going to be a change from what they’ve been doing.  But in terms of the overall financial situation and the way the economy and pricing is going to be, I just don’t think it’s a very big effect quickly.  And the fact that it’s going to take place over more than three years I think people can understand, and how it’s going to build.According to our estimates of term premia, which have gone down due to the size of our balance sheet, we’ve got some estimates—the balance sheet is only going to change slowly.  It’s not going to be in a surprise fashion.  So, you know, one would think the taper tantrums that happened back in the spring and summer of 2013, nobody should be wrong-footed, you know, because they didn’t expect this.  I mean, if they weren’t paying attention, somebody—you know, people have to be accountable for things like that.  But I think that there’s been enough talking and planning over this that it should go smoothly.  And I think that it’s the kind of thing that can run in the background and not have a tremendous effect on adjusting the stance of financial restrictiveness.  So I think that it could take place.The hurdle for not doing that, I think, could be quite high, given that we’ve said, you know, we expect to do this this year.  The hurdle for not making a funds rate adjustment, that I think is actually the live option if you think that something is happening with the economy or inflation that you weren’t expecting.  Having said that, I think everybody’s forecast expectation for the economy is strong fundamentals, continued growth, continued improvement in labor markets, and, you know, two, three, maybe four rate hikes this year.Q:  So when the balance-sheet action does start happening, you’re not necessarily expecting to see, say, yields start to just push up higher?  That’s not something you necessarily expect to see happen?MR. EVANS:  I would not expect that.  I do not expect that.  Can’t rule anything out, of course.And, you know, I mean, the challenges with financial markets and yields—you know, last night there was the question about the 10-year Treasury rate’s come down a lot and, you know, what do you think about that.  And you have to stop and remember that the Treasury—10-year Treasury rate was, you know, quite low until the election, and then the election, and then optimism from the business community about, you know, tax plans and regulatory relief and things like that, and, you know, 10-year rates shot up by a considerable amount, and they continue to build for a while.  You know, then you have, you know, more British discussions about Brexit, elections, things like that; U.S. is a safe haven; people have slightly different expectations of legislative activity in Washington; and, you know, 10-year rates move down.Now, how much of that is because of our actions?  Probably not much, if any.  How much of it is everything else going on?  I’m in the everything else going on camp.  But that’s a big bucket, so.Q:  It seems like there’s an effort to—you know, once this thing is put into motion, to have it go sort of automatically in the background.  Is there sort of—what would have to happen to kind of take the balance-sheet reduction off this automated path?MR. EVANS:  Yeah, so once we get started—you know, and we expect that it can take place in the background—as we, you know, find ourselves confronting different expectations for the economic growth, the labor market, or inflation, our first tool, I would say, is adjusting the funds rate.  So, if we see more inflation and we can go a little—need to go faster, unemployment rate goes down lower, we can, you know, adjust upwards the funds rate path.  If we’re not seeing progress on inflation, we don’t go as fast.You know, if something more unexpected and negative happened and we needed to provide more accommodation, you could—you could first think about reducing the funds rate.  Now, this is not my expectation at all; you know, not the most likely event.  But you could still adjust the interest rate and not necessarily make any adjustments to the balance sheet.  But if you think that you’re at risk of something much deeper than that and you expect that you might hit the zero lower bound—because we’re only at 1 1/8 right now—then, yeah, you could easily stop the balance sheet, and you could even choose to add assets if you were in very unfortunate circumstances.  But, of course, that’s the full toolkit on display, not what I’m expecting.Q:  Do you reckon whenever the next recession comes around that there’s going to be the balance sheet—adjusting the balance sheet is going to be part of the reaction?MR. EVANS:  So I spend most of my time speaking in public about how difficult the risks of the zero lower bound are for monetary policy.  I think that when we get down to zero, it’s a very challenging environment.  I think that when other government actors don’t choose to take actions which help provide additional aggregate demand through fiscal policy or through other actions, that makes our job that much more difficult.  And, you know, unless we’re willing to just sort of stop and say it’s not our responsibility—I don’t think that’s the way the Federal Reserve Act reads—then we have to do more, and then I think that that means more asset purchases.Now, in Europe and Japan, they’ve looked at negative interest rates.  And we didn’t ever—I do not recall us ever meaningfully talking about negative interest rates back in 2009, you know, at that time.  I don’t think that’s an option that many people would like.  And so, if we end up having an inflation objective of 2%, if we find ourselves without enough headroom in order to reduce the funds rate enough in order to get the economy, you know, bottomed and growing again, then more stimulus comes from asset purchases.  I’d prefer not to have to do that.Q:  Do you think Chair Yellen deserves to be reappointed as chair at the end of her term?MR. EVANS:  I think Chair Yellen is terrific.  Yes, I do think she’s, you know, definitely worthy of that.  I think she’s done a great job in the transition from Ben Bernanke as chair.  She’s guided us through, you know, the wind-down of those policies and gotten us to the point where we’ve begun renormalization.  She understands the current situation extremely well.Now, I’ve said some things where I say, you know, I’m not so sure about the effect of the labor market for inflation, and the Phillips curve is very flat, and Chair Yellen understands all of these issues very well.  I think at some point you have to, you know, place your bets.  I think she’s guided the committee extremely well.  You know, she’d be terrific.  But, you know, it’s a presidential appointment.  One can never know how those things play out.
news_title: Transcript: Fed’s Evans Discusses Inflation, Interest Rates, Balance Sheet

content: New Orleans real-estate developer and entrepreneur       Sidney Torres IV       has won accolades for his success in cleaning up the French Quarter after Hurricane Katrina and for fighting crime in the storied historic district, sometimes spending his own money.But the achievements have done little to damp the outrage some preservationists have expressed over Mr. Torres’s renovation of the 4,600-square-foot house and stable building he purchased in the district four years ago.Some of the work didn’t get the proper permits from the city’s Vieux Carre Commission, which oversees the French Quarter, and preservationists say he should be forced to undo it.Mr. Torres, a host of the new CNBC home improvement show “The Deed” and a possible candidate for New Orleans mayor this year, acknowledges mistakes were made by his contractor but says the house has remained well within the character of the neighborhood.“These are things that would have been approved anyway,” he said in an interview.Earlier this month, Mr. Torres reached a tentative compromise with the commission that requires him to report back in one month on modifying a few of the changes he had made. But preservationists remain unhappy and say he should be required to undo many more.“What we have before us is a prime example of the adage that it’s easier to ask for forgiveness than ask for permission,” said Meg Lousteau, executive director of Vieux Carre Property Owners, Residents and Associates, at a June 7 commission meeting. She added that Mr. Torres’s reputation for doing good in the district shouldn’t make a difference.“I would be saying this if the applicant were Pope Francis himself,” she said.The donnybrook highlights the hazards developers face when working in some of the country’s most loved historic districts. The rules in the French Quarter are particularly strict. Any change to a property’s exterior, including roofs, interior courtyards and driveways, needs to be approved by the Vieux Carre Commission, named after the old French term for the French Quarter.Mr. Torres said he originally purchased the brick house, built just before the Civil War at 730 Esplanade Ave., thinking he would upgrade it and sell. But it was in “deplorable condition” and he said he soon realized it wouldn’t work as an investment. He estimated his cost of buying the property, carrying costs and other expenses at about $3 million.So he decided to make it his home. For the next few years he worked on extensive plans to add air conditioning and a swimming pool, add skylights, replace doors and windows and renovate its architectural features.As work proceeded, Mr. Torres obtained the necessary permits from the city’s Department of Safety and Permits. The Vieux Carre Commission approved some of the upgrades, such as painting and adding the swimming pool.But according to a staff report made at the recent commission meeting, the panel didn’t review and approve such work as the installation of new rooftop mechanical equipment, the addition of 14 skylights, the addition of a new second-floor window, the alteration of an arched transom and the construction of a new courtyard enclosure wall.Mr. Torres’s lawyer,       Justin Schmidt,        said at the meeting the project “highlighted some flaws” in a new approval process the city had put in place. Permits were issued by Department of Safety and Permits “without the VCC certificate of appropriateness being issued at the same time,” he said.“The fact that Safety and Permits at the end of the day issued permits that had not been reviewed by the VCC is now being placed on the contractor and/or applicant and/or owner,” he said.Nicholas Musso,        the commission chairman, responded by saying, “The onus is on the contractor and/or applicant and/or owner.”As part of the tentative compromise reached with the commission, Mr. Torres’s legal and architectural team agreed to study some changes, including restoring the arched transom that was removed. Mr. Torres’s team agreed to remove the second-floor window that was added unless they can find a photo proving that the window had been there originally but was subsequently covered up. But most of the other changes will be allowed to remain.If the commission had taken a harder line, Mr. Torres could have appealed to the city council. Mr. Musso, the commission chairman, said at the meeting he wanted to avoid such a scenario.“I certainly don’t want to see a confrontation with the city council, who I consider not particularly well-informed about the nature of place or the nature of the Vieux Carre in particular,” he said.Write to Peter Grant at peter.grant@wsj.com
news_title: TV Show Host Sidney Torres in Hot Water Over French Quarter Upgrades

content: WASHINGTON -- President       Donald Trump,        under pressure to respond to the death of an American student after his detention by North Korea, said Tuesday that China has been unable to crack down on North Korea, pointing to a new direction for U.S. policies.“While I greatly appreciate the efforts of President Xi & China to help with North Korea, it has not worked out,” Mr. Trump said in a             Twitter                   message. “At least I know China tried.”Chinese President       Xi Jinping       visited Mr. Trump at his Florida resort in April, and the two agreed to work together to address North Korea’s nuclear weapons and missile programs. In the weeks since, Mr. Trump has praised Mr. Xi. But his Twitter message Tuesday indicated that the effort has ended in failure.Only moments earlier, White House press secretary       Sean Spicer       said in a news briefing that Washington and Beijing have made progress on pressuring North Korea and are looking to do more.“We’ll continue to work with them and others to put the appropriate pressure on North Korea,” Mr. Spicer said.White House officials didn’t immediately explain the disparate messages.Senior Chinese officials are due in Washington on Wednesday to huddle with Secretary of State       Rex Tillerson       and Defense Secretary       Jim Mattis.Until Mr. Trump’s announcement Tuesday, administration officials had been saying he is seeking to cooperate with China to pressure North Korea to alter its drive for nuclear missiles. By abandoning that option, Mr. Trump faces a short list of alternatives that all are considered problematic. One is to impose so-called secondary sanctions that would penalize companies that do business with North Korea. China is bitterly opposed to such sanctions because the bulk of outside firms and banks doing business with Pyongyang are Chinese.The Trump administration recently asked China to act against around 10 Chinese companies and individuals trading with North Korea, saying that doing so would disrupt key networks that support North Korea’s nuclear weapons program.The U.S. hadn’t set a deadline but has indicated the Treasury Department could impose unilateral sanctions on some of the entities before the end of the summer if Beijing doesn’t act.Another option is an outright ban on U.S. tourism. State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert said Tuesday that Mr. Tillerson is considering whether to halt all travel by Americans to North Korea.The Trump administration also could attempt diplomacy with North Korea, as Mr. Trump previously has suggested, although Mr. Spicer played down prospects Tuesday. “Clearly, we’re moving further away, not closer to, those conditions being intact,” he said.American diplomats had been holding secret talks in Pyongyang and European cities with North Korea’s top nuclear negotiator for more than a year, hoping to free U.S. prisoners and possibly establish a diplomatic channel to constrain North Korea’s nuclear and missile programs.Officials with the Chinese embassy in Washington didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.On Monday, 22-year-old       Otto Warmbier,        a University of Virginia student, died in a Cincinnati hospital. He had been released from North Korea after 17 months in captivity and was in a coma after apparently falling ill months earlier without the knowledge of U.S. officials or his family.His family said he came home unable to speak, see or respond to voice commands.After the disclosure on Monday of Mr. Warmbier’s death, U.S. lawmakers demanded that North Korea be held to account for his treatment.Sen. Ben Cardin (D., Md.), the senior Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said       Kim Jong Un’s       “repressive murderous regime” deserves blame for Mr. Warmbier’s death.“They must be held accountable for their continued barbaric behavior,” he said in a statement.Sen.       John McCain       (R., Ariz.), chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the U.S. “cannot and should not tolerate the murder of its citizens by hostile powers.”A county coroner in Mr. Warmbier’s home state of Ohio announced an investigation into his death. Physicians said he had a severe brain injury, the cause of which remains unclear.Mr. Trump earlier Tuesday said that what happened to Mr. Warmbier is “a total disgrace.”“That should never, ever be allowed to happen,” Mr. Trump told reporters, when asked about Mr. Warmbier’s death. “Frankly, if he were brought home sooner, I think the result would have been a lot different.”Mr. Trump didn’t spell out say how he would respond to Mr. Warmbier’s death. His Twitter message came several hours later.Mr. Warmbier’s release from North Korean detention had been discussed by U.S. and North Korean officials through the secret diplomatic channel set up earlier. The State Department’s special representative for North Korea, Joseph Yun, met North Korean officials for talks in Oslo last month but wasn’t told about Mr. Warmbier’s deteriorating health, U.S. officials said.It was only on June 6, when Mr. Yun talked to Pyongyang’s deputy ambassador to the United Nations in another meeting in New York that the U.S. was told of the American’s condition.Mr. Yun went to Pyongyang last week with a team of doctors to bring Mr. Warmbier home. He also met with three other Americans detained in North Korea. Ms. Nauert, the State Department spokeswoman, said Tuesday that she couldn’t comment on their condition.South Korea’s President Moon Jae-In is set to visit Washington and meet with Mr. Trump later this month.—Rebecca Ballhaus contributed to this article.Write to Felicia Schwartz at Felicia.Schwartz@wsj.com
news_title: Trump Says China Failed to Help U.S. With North Korea Problems

content: The New York City official whose agency oversees much of the contracts for the superstorm Sandy recovery program is stepping down, people familiar with the matter said Tuesday.Feniosky Peña-Mora is the commissioner of the New York City Department of Design and Construction, which helps oversee capital projects in the city from the building of libraries and police precincts to water-main construction, sewers and other infrastructure. Dr. Peña-Mora has led the agency since 2014, when he was appointed by Mayor       Bill de Blasio.A request for comment to the DDC wasn’t immediately returned Tuesday afternoon.Under Mr. Peña-Mora, the Department of Design and Construction, has overseen about $1 billion in contracts related to Build it Back, the city’s program to rebuild and elevate homes damaged in the 2012 storm known as Sandy. Build it Back is significantly delayed and at least half a billion over budget, largely because of cost overruns in DDC-managed projects in the initiative.A spokeswoman for Mr. de Blasio declined to comment. The mayor said on NY1 Monday evening he wished he had approached superstorm Sandy recovery differently. “We are never going to do this the same way,” the mayor said.Write to Mara Gay at mara.gay@wsj.com
news_title: Head of New York City Infrastructure Agency Stepping Down

content: Back in the days when music was sold only on LP or CD, a large-format package was merely expected to serve as a delivery system for the performances themselves. (Perhaps that’s why one of the first big sets that I ever owned, the 20-CD “Frank       Sinatra      —The Complete Reprise Studio Recordings” from 1995, was housed in a small suitcase.) Now, in the age of sound files and streaming music, any kind of physical medium seems like a fetish object, and the package in which it is contained even more so. Clearly, size matters, and the past few years have seen huge boxed sets covering the complete catalogs of such legacy artists as       Elvis Presley       (60 CDs),       Johnny Cash       (62),       Miles Davis       (72) and       Tony Bennett       (76).But these pop, country and jazz packages pale besides those collecting the works of classical superstars, such as instrumentalists       Yo Yo Ma       (90 CDs) and       Arthur Rubinstein       (94). And even they are dwarfed by packages representing composers, such as “      Mozart       225: The New Complete Edition” (200 CDs) released last fall. With 240 CDs dedicated to the conductor and a $1,330 list price, “      Herbert von Karajan      : Complete Recordings on Deutsche Grammophon,” issued in Japan, is surely a contender for the biggest and most expensive package yet.The latest entry in the big-box stakes is “The Jazz & Blues Artbox,” produced by the Swiss jazz impresario, trumpeter and entrepreneur       Hans Zurbrügg       with the cooperation of Swiss TV. Here are the numbers: 230 DVDs containing that many concerts from the Bern Jazz Festival from 1983 to 2002, a total of roughly 400 hours of music, as well as 96 interviews with the artists (included on the DVDs as bonus material), 20 booklets (one for each year), and, as the press release puts it, one 344-page “large format” book, all housed in a “tasteful cabinet.” Only 5,000 copies are being produced. More than ever before, you’re not just buying music (and video). You’re buying furniture—even real estate. The list price is $8,400; no, it’s not exactly an impulse purchase. (You’ll also need a home theater; watching this on a standard-size computer monitor or TV set just won’t do.)Excerpts shown in a teaser trailer on YouTube and at a launch event at the New School earlier this month are enough to make this jazz fan’s mouth water:       Joe Williams       challenging       Dizzy Gillespie       to a blues/scat battle with the full Count Basie Orchestra as backdrop;       Art Blakey       appearing with an all-star version of his Jazz Messengers including       Freddie Hubbard       and       Benny Golson      ;       Sarah Vaughan       reacting to the presence of trumpet great       Clark Terry       in her audience. While the earlier concerts showcase already established greats, like       Benny Carter       and       Woody Herman,        gradually more younger stars become visible, like Bill Charlap playing piano with       Gerry Mulligan’s       last great quartet and       Wynton Marsalis       leading his 1990 sextet with       Wycliffe Gordon.The interviews are also priceless, such as Mulligan explaining the origin of his famous “pianoless” quartet, and Art Blakey recalling how he was originally forced to switch from piano to drums by a gangster at gunpoint. (When the lights came back on at the New School after an excerpt from this interview, Mr. Marsalis, who was also present at the launch event, told the house, “Yeah, Art liked to make up stories like that.”)Still, this boxed set raises the question of whether some of these packages have now grown so large as to be parodies of themselves. I personally don’t know any jazz fan who has the means to purchase such a package. Then there’s the time factor: Only younger jazz fans are likely to have the time left in their lives to watch, listen to, and enjoy all this amazing music. (As of this writing, 156 of the sets have been sold.)Seeing as they’ve released remarkable performances in a package that’s so enormous and overwhelmingly expensive that virtually no one can afford it, one has to wonder what purpose it actually serves.Whatever the motivation, unless the producers start to release some of the music in smaller sets or find some other way of distributing the music, like through streaming or subscription services—which Mr. Zurbrügg has said that they do not intend to do—the best that dedicated listeners can do is hope our local libraries invest in a set and pray that no other jazz fan gets there before we do.—Mr. Friedwald writes about music and popular culture for the Journal.
news_title: Boxed Sets Are Bigger Than Ever—But Who Buys Them?
keywords: arts in review, blues,boxed set, jazz, jazz & plues art box, music,political,general news,arts,entertainment,music,reviews

content: U.S. stock indexes retreated Tuesday as oil prices slipped to their lowest levels since September, pressuring the shares of energy companies.Stock losses were broad, pulling nine of the S&P 500’s 11 sectors lower. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average fell after both climbed to fresh closing records Monday.Energy stocks in the S&P 500 fell 1.2%, deepening losses for the index’s worst-performing sector of the year. The moves came as fresh fears over an oversupply of oil sent U.S. crude into a bear market, or down 20% from its previous high.Rising production around the world has offset efforts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to draw down a glut, analysts say. Crude for July delivery fell 2.2% to $43.23 a barrel on Tuesday, its lowest settlement since Sept. 16.While the energy sector is expected to account for nearly half of the S&P 500’s earnings growth for the second quarter, according to FactSet, analysts say broad strength across sectors should help stocks keep climbing.“I’m not too worried about it yet,” said       David Lefkowitz,        senior equity strategist at UBS Wealth Management Americas. “Business confidence is high, bank-lending standards are easing and the outlook for stocks looks pretty good.”The Dow industrials fell 61.85 points, or 0.3%, to 21467.14. The             Nasdaq Co      mposite lost 50.98 points, or 0.8%, to 6188.03 and the S&P 500 shed 16.43 points, or 0.7%, to 2437.03.Health-care companies rose 0.3% in the S&P 500 and were one of two sectors in the index to gain Tuesday.             Regeneron Pharmaceuticals                   rose $23.66, or 5%, to $495.33 after investment bank Piper Jaffray lifted the stock’s price target.             Alexion Pharmaceuticals                   rose 2.89, or 2.5%, to 119.05 and             Incyte                   rose 2.30, or 1.9%, to 124.58.Consumer-discretionary stocks fell 1.2% in the S&P 500, posting the biggest losses of the index’s sectors for the day.             Chipotle Mexican Grill                   lost 33.31, or 7.3%, to 425.60,             Ross Stores                   lost 2.93, or 4.8%, to 57.72 and             Kohl’s                   lost 1.50, or 4%, to 36.03.Government bonds edged higher, with the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note falling to 2.153%, its third-lowest settlement of the year, from 2.188% Monday. Yields fall as bond prices rise.Elsewhere, the Stoxx Europe 600 fell 0.7%, pulled lower by oil and mining companies.Japan’s Nikkei Stock Average rose 0.8% Tuesday to its highest close since August 2015 after the dollar strengthened against the yen, supporting exporters.Hong Kong’s             Hang Seng                   Index dropped 0.3%, and the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.1%.Write to Akane Otani at akane.otani@wsj.com and Riva Gold at riva.gold@wsj.comAppeared in the June 21, 2017, print edition as 'Stocks Fall Broadly as Nine of 11 Sectors End Lower.'
news_title: U.S. Stocks Slide as Oil Slump Hits Energy Sector

content: The retail-property outlook has worsened in the past year, but some investors are betting that shares of mall landlords have gotten too cheap.Real-estate investment trusts tied to retail property have been the worst performers among all REITs this year, falling 15.6% compared with a 1.6% gain for the category overall and a 7.7% gain for the S&P 500-stock index.But some investors believe sector sentiment is overly negative and shares are a bargain.“We believe the stocks have come down to fair value for the risk that we’re taking,” said       Joel Beam,        managing director and senior portfolio manager of real estate strategies at asset management firm Salient Partners LP.Salient in January began picking up shares of mall REITs such as             CBL & Associates Properties Inc.       The shares have fallen further since, and the firm’s investors have questioned the moves. CBL, a Chattanooga, Tenn-based mall owner, is down 27% this year.Mr. Beam said malls should be good investments for the next three to five years, adding that CBL’s portfolio is in good shape and property values will hold.“It just has to get rid of a few turkeys,” Mr. Beam said, referring to underperforming malls.Some investors say they are taking advantage of the selloff to add to their exposure of blue-chip retail landlords.       Matthew Werner,        managing director at Chilton Capital Management LLC, said his West Loop Realty Fund recently invested in mall REITs such as             Simon Property Group Inc.       and in the past six to 12 months has doubled its holdings of             GGP Inc.“This is one of the most attractive investment opportunities these days,” said Mr. Werner. “Class A malls are one of the most profitable distribution centers for retailers.”He added that short sellers of mall REITs might be getting ahead of themselves.“How many of them understand the value proposition of each mall?” he said.Write to Esther Fung at esther.fung@wsj.com
news_title: Contrarian Investors Dive Into Mall REITs

content: DUNWOODY, Ga.—The nationally watched House special election in Georgia is the most significant test of strength for the two parties since       Donald Trump       became president, and both are worried that a defeat there would demoralize their party heading into the 2018 midterm elections.With a record $60 million poured into Georgia’s 6th Congressional District in the Atlanta suburbs, both parties are leaving nothing on the field in the contest between Democrat       Jon Ossoff       and Republican Karen Handel.Democrats worry that an Ossoff defeat will show limits to their ability to turn the grass-roots wave of anti-Trump sentiment into electoral gains in 2018. They are hungry for a victory in Georgia, because they have lost in two other proxy battles, in House special elections in Kansas and Montana.Republicans fear that losing a seat their party has held for almost four decades could suggest that the Trump presidency will take a political toll on the party in the midterms, especially in suburban battleground districts.With polls showing the Ossoff-Handel campaign ending in a dead heat and with few voters undecided, both candidates agreed this week on one thing: The only thing left to do in the final days was make sure that their supporters got to the polls.“Let’s summon everything we’ve got to out-work, out-hustle, out-fight,” Mr. Ossoff told his supporters on Tuesday via             Twitter.Ms. Handel continued to prod Republicans by portraying Mr.Ossoff as an ally of liberal Democratic leaders such as House Minority Leader       Nancy Pelosi       of California, even though he has run on a centrist campaign message.“Republicans are motivated,” Ms. Handel said in a CNN interview. “They surely don’t want Nancy Pelosi’s guy coming in.”Election Day brought torrential rains and flash flood warnings to the district. More than 140,308 people had already voted in early balloting, according to the Georgia Secretary of State’s office. That was almost three times the 56,830 people who voted early in the first round of balloting in April, during the special-election primary that winnowed an 18-candidate field. Tuesday’s run-off was needed because no candidate in April won more than 50% of the vote, although Mr. Ossoff came close, with 48%.The race is seen as potential bellwether for the 2018 midterm elections, because key battlegrounds in the fight for control of the House are likely to be suburban, affluent GOP districts like Georgia’s 6th. Mr. Trump struggled in many of these districts in 2016.White House spokesman       Sean Spicer       played down the race’s broader significance. “If you look historically, special elections generally don’t foretell the outcome of races multiple years down the road,” he said.The race could affect the president’s ability to move legislation through Congress.  A GOP defeat could spook Republican incumbents about the political risks of sticking with Mr. Trump on policy and perhaps make them more fearful of supporting a major overhaul of health care, which was a big issue in the Georgia race.The special election outcome also could shape the candidate field for the 2018 midterm elections, making it easier for the prevailing party to recruit candidates for the House. Republicans are already facing a tough political environment, because the party holding the White House typically loses seats in a midterm election.Democrats hoped a victory in Georgia would move them one seat closer to the House majority they aim to win in 2018. A loss would leave them having to defeat an incumbent to win back the seat, and certainly with less money than was available in the special election. In the midterms, the Democratic Party will be mounting challenges to dozens of GOP incumbents at once, though some will be in districts not tilted as heavily to the GOP as the seat in Georgia.The district has been held by the Republican Party since       Newt Gingrich       won it in 1978. Democrats have made it a test of their political strength, because Mr. Trump barely won the district in 2016. The seat came open this year when Mr. Trump chose Rep.       Tom Price       to be secretary of health and human services.The president, who attended a fundraiser for Ms. Handel in April, put more of his own political capital on the line in series of tweets Monday and Tuesday supporting her and attacking Mr. Ossoff.Urging his followers to vote for Ms. Handel, Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter, “She will fight for lower taxes, great healthcare strong security-a hard worker who will never give up!”The record $60 million poured into the race has included $31.4 by Mr. Ossoff and his supporters and $23.4 by Ms. Handel and her allies, according to an analysis of Federal Election Commission filings by Issue One, a bipartisan campaign finance group.The result has been a campaign that has saturated the district with fliers, television and digital ads—most of them negative—and door-to-door canvassing so intense that it has left many voters feeling beleaguered and eager to see the campaign end.“I’m voting! I’ve heard so much about the campaign! I’m voting!’’ said one Marietta resident who slammed the door on a canvasser for a conservative group, the Faith and Freedom Coalition.Cobb County voter Dianne Poland, who supported Ms. Handel in the race, has kept a growing pile of political mail under her living room table. “I thought I’d have a bonfire!” she said of her post-election plans.Voters in both camps expressed a desire for change, even if they found hope in different candidates.“I would worry we would just get back to the same old, same old” if Ms. Handel won, said Carla Edwards, an Ossoff supporter from Dunwoody, who said she voted for Mr. Price in the past.Jack Williams, a Handel supporter in Dunwoody, worried about the big influx of money from Democratic donors outside the district that helped Mr. Ossoff compete.“I hope like the Dickens Karen wins so it might stop all of this nonsense from the Democrats, though it probably won’t,” he said.—Shelby Holliday contributed to this article.Write to Janet Hook at janet.hook@wsj.com and Cameron McWhirter at cameron.mcwhirter@wsj.comAppeared in the June 21, 2017, print edition as 'Both Parties Fear Georgia Defeat.'

content: U.S. oil prices tumbled into a bear market on Tuesday as the oversupply concerns that have roiled markets over the past few weeks put further pressure on investors.Bets that global exporters could ease a supply glut through a historic agreement to cut output have been undermined as production has increased in the U.S., Libya and Nigeria. Global inventories of crude oil and oil products have remained high, compounding on worries that rebalancing the global oil market will be harder than previously thought.Light, sweet crude for July delivery settled down 97 cents, or 2.2%, at $43.23 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, more than 20% below this year’s high of $54.45 on Feb. 23. Brent, the global benchmark, settled down 89 cents, or 1.9%, to $46.02 a barrel.Tuesday’s close put oil in a bear market for the first time since August 2016, before the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and other major oil-producing nations agreed to limit output by about 1.8 million barrels a day at the end of last year. In May, the group renewed the deal through March 2018.The extended drop in oil prices is another worrying sign for OPEC, analysts said, which has struggled to put a dent in global inventories and keep oil prices supported.“We’re seeing this decline amid some major OPEC production restraints,” said Jim Ritterbusch, president of energy-advisory firm Ritterbusch & Associates. “That’s the huge difference” compared with previous bear markets.U.S. companies have also ramped up shale production in response to higher prices this year, helping to offset impacts made by the OPEC cut, analysts said.Traders have been watching U.S. inventory levels, which have added to the bearish sentiment in recent weeks. With momentum pushing the market lower, even traders who believe output cuts are putting the market closer to a supply shortage aren’t willing to place bets on that until after the U.S. government’s influential weekly report on storage levels, due Wednesday morning, said Scott Shelton, broker at             ICAP                   PLC.“Most of the bulls are waiting on statistics, and they’re not going to stand in front of this thing until then,” he said.The U.S. Energy Information Administration report is scheduled for release at 10:30 a.m. ET on Wednesday. Analysts and traders surveyed by The Wall Street Journal expect crude stockpiles to fall by 2 million barrels, on average, in the week ended June 16.Even amid falling crude stockpiles in the U.S., oil prices have dropped as tepid stock draws have failed to impress investors. Tuesday’s move marked oil’s eighth loss of more than 2% in just the past two months.“Barring a major draw that surprises people that’s well over expectations, it’s probably not going to provide much in the way of support,” said John Saucer, vice president of research and analysis at Mobius Risk Group. “The market’s definitely been very receptive to bearish news.”The American Petroleum Institute, an industry group, said late Tuesday that its own data for the week showed a 2.7-million-barrel decrease in crude supplies, a 346,000-barrel rise in gasoline stocks and a 1.8-million-barrel increase in distillate inventories, according to a market participant.Gasoline futures fell 1.8% to $1.4240 a gallon and diesel futures lost 1.1% to $1.3949 a gallon.Write to Stephanie Yang at stephanie.yang@wsj.com and Timothy Puko at tim.puko@wsj.com

content: The dollar headed for its highest closing level in a month Tuesday as investors grew more optimistic that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again this year.The WSJ Dollar Index, which measures the U.S. currency against 16 others, rose 0.3% to 88.98, which would mark its highest closing level since May 18.The dollar was supported by comments made Monday by New York Fed President       William Dudley,        expressing confidence in the U.S. economy and the prospect for higher inflation.“Inflation’s a little bit lower than what we would like,” he said. “But we think if the labor market continues to tighten, wages will gradually pick up, and with that we’ll see inflation get back to 2%.”The comments indicate that the Fed remains on track to raise rates again this year. Investors have worried that a recent slowdown in inflation would sideline the central bank.Fed-funds futures, a popular tool for betting on the Fed’s rate policy outlook, show a 51% chance that the Fed raises rates again this year, according to CME Group. That is up from 41% a day earlier.Higher rates typically support the dollar by making U.S. assets more attractive to yield-seeking investors.Oil-dependent currencies came under pressure as U.S. oil prices officially entered a bear market amid oversupply concerns. The dollar rose 0.3% against the Canadian dollar, 1.8% against the Russian ruble, and 0.5% against the Norwegian krone.Meanwhile, the British pound slid 0.8% to $1.2636 after Bank of England Governor       Mark Carney       pushed back against speculation that the central bank could lift rates soon.Write to Chelsey Dulaney at Chelsey.Dulaney@wsj.com
news_title: Dollar Rises on Revived Interest Rate Hopes
